name: Glivenko-Cantelli Theorem
description:
Let $X_1, X_2, \ldots, X_n$ be iid random variables defined on $(\Omega, \mathbb{P})$ that follow an unknown CDF $F$. The Glivenko-Cantelli tells us that the error within an empirical CDF $F_n(\omega, t)$ goes to $0$ as our number of samples $n$ is large. Namely, it asserts:
$$\mathbb{P}\left(\left\{ \omega\in\Omega : \lim_{n\rightarrow\infty} \left(\sup_t|Fn(\omega,t)-F(t)|=0\right)\right\}\right)=1$$
